I thoroughly enjoyed the game when I had it. I got bored of it fast though, but decided to pick it up again. It's a fun game, but a little imbalanced when it comes to what ship you're flying and what ship is shooting at you. It makes sense though, because an tackler should be able to take down a gunship easily, and a gunship should be able to destroy an interceptor pretty quickly.  I'm a little upset on how the frigates work though. It takes a good amount of time before you get your first damaging frigate, and even then it's expensive to arm it with the weapons you wish to take into battle.  If anyone is familiar with the World of Tanks series, then you know how most of the game works.  Two teams composed of pilots flying different ships playing in one of the gamemode types. You choose what ships you want to take into battle, three at the most. If you leave the battle, then those three ships become locked until the end of the battle. There is a respawn in the control beacon game mode, but there is no respawn in search and destroy or any of the other arena style gamemodes.  After all of this though, I still enjoy flying a frigate into a swarm of fighters and winning against all the odds. If that's not you then you'd probably be interested in flying an interceptor capable of in-battle warp jumps, or a tackler that uses a beam to slow ships and paint them for extra damage. All in all it's a really fun game when you know what you're doing.

Star Conflict reminds me of War Thunder with a look of EVE Online and I love it.  Pro's- Spectacular graphics Smooth controls In-game voice chat Oculus Rift and Joystick compatable 6 PVP gamemodes and a large variety of maps Open world PVE as well as 9 co-op PVE mission instances, starting off at lvl 1 3 different factions you can choose to fight and fulfill contracts for at any time 138 standard ships and 63 premium ($$) Large varity of weapons, utilities and cosmetics (camo coloring and decals) Not pay to win (of course spending money will give you a slight advangtage but when will it not in a f2p?) Log-in with Steam account, no need to make a seperate account in-game  Con's- You have to watch your mouth around the admins (they're not nice people, very ban/mute happy) The grind is real  AI can have its moments Smaller community (Mostly Friendly) Upper tiers aren't as populated as lower tiers, reducing the content to a 3rd of its potential A little repetitive No PVE story-line, quest-line, or campaign  Open-world PVE missions are daily quests, recieving only one or two at a time  Overall, one of the better F2P games I've played and one of the best of its kind. Easily deserves a thumbs up and a try, even if you only play for the first few tiers (about 10 hours of fun gameplay for each faction).  8/10  Space. I love space.

This game is a nice blend of CoD and EVE Online. A quick and consise tutorial gets you into the game real fast. I can see myself sinking quite a number of hours into this one. Love the fact that it is native on Linux and it's Free to Play, not Free to Win. While it is possible to spend a good amount of real money and deck out you ship(s), at the same time, there is quite a bit of skill involved during actual combat, so you won't be dominated by someone who has spent $100 but has no experience in-game. Also, if you're worried about being a newbie and jumping into a match only to be constantly killed and frustrated, there are a number of PvE levels to play that offer nice rewards, which will then allow you to deck out your ship(s) before diving into PvP territory. Haven't had a chance to check out the corporations yet, but that appears to be a nice bit of endgame once you've reached a really high level, have a strong grasp on the game, and you have all three (or four) ship slots filled with decent equipment and such.  I would highly reccomend this game for sci-fi nerds like me, and those who enjoy Call of Duty, EVE, or even the Wing Commander series... In fact, when I first got in-game, I was having some flash-backs of Tie Fighter (the Jericho faction is very remenicent of the Sith).
Great game with great mechanics and even greater ships.

1. Microtransactions. Star Conflict is one of few games where microtransactions are limited in very uneasy manner. Willing to buy lvl13 Premium ship from scratch? Suck it, buy lvl3, lvl5, lvl7, lvl9 and lvl11 ships first (preferrably Premium ones, of course)! Pretty fair, ain't it? (the idea of limiting purchaseability of paid items in F2P game is worth Economics Ig Nobel Prize, honestly) Oh, barely forgot. You won't unlock all Steam achievements without purchasing at least one ship for real money. Ain't that cute? 2. Game mechanics. Rocket launchers and torpedoes rule. Is your ship tough as nails? Suck it, one guided missile in your side and you're done! Lasers, ballistics guns, stealth devices, crowd control devices - nothing of it needed if you can just spam rockets. 3. Bots. Bots everywhere. The game itself is all about quick skirmishes between small squads. Each botter present diminishes team's chances way too seriously.

Multiplayer in space......what more can I say!!!! After spending some time with the game I find myself going back to it so I can level up and get bigger, better ships. The multiplayer action is great fun and I've yet to experience some of the other PvE, galaxy conquest etc. Quick battles are matched on your level so you are playing with similar players which makes for a more fun experience.   The only issue Ive had to date is finding some of the options in the game but over all is not a huge issue and Im sure with more time that wont be a problem.
